user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SelectSingle_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SelectSingle_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 *SelectFlags, int32 msecs)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    fd_set                          wr_set;
    fd_set                          rd_set;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /*
     * If called on a stream_id which does not support this
     * operation, return immediately and do not invoke the system call
     */
    if (!impl->selectable)
    {
        return OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED;
    }

    if (impl->fd >= FD_SETSIZE)
    {
        /* out of range of select() implementation */
        return OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED;
    }

    if (*SelectFlags != 0)
    {
        FD_ZERO(&wr_set);
        FD_ZERO(&rd_set);
        if (*SelectFlags & OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE)
        {
            FD_SET(impl->fd, &rd_set);
        }
        if (*SelectFlags & OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE)
        {
            FD_SET(impl->fd, &wr_set);
        }

        return_code = OS_DoSelect(impl->fd, &rd_set, &wr_set, msecs);

        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            if (!FD_ISSET(impl->fd, &rd_set))
            {
                *SelectFlags &= ~OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE;
            }
            if (!FD_ISSET(impl->fd, &wr_set))
            {
                *SelectFlags &= ~OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE;
            }
        }
        else
        {
            *SelectFlags = 0;
        }
    }
    else
    {
        /* Nothing to check for, return immediately. */
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SelectSingle_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
static int32 OS_DoSelect(int maxfd, fd_set *rd_set, fd_set *wr_set, int32 msecs)
{
    int             os_status;
    int32           return_code;
    struct timeval  tv;
    struct timeval *tvptr;
    struct timespec ts_now;
    struct timespec ts_end;

    if (msecs > 0)
    {
        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &ts_now);
        ts_end.tv_sec  = ts_now.tv_sec + (msecs / 1000);
        ts_end.tv_nsec = ts_now.tv_nsec + (1000000 * (msecs % 1000));
        if (ts_end.tv_nsec >= 1000000000)
        {
            ++ts_end.tv_sec;
            ts_end.tv_nsec -= 1000000000;
        }
    }
    else
    {
        /* Zero for consistency and to avoid possible confusion if not cleared */
        memset(&ts_end, 0, sizeof(ts_end));
    }

    do
    {
        if (msecs < 0)
        {
            tvptr = NULL;
        }
        else if (msecs == 0)
        {
            tvptr      = &tv;
            tv.tv_sec  = 0;
            tv.tv_usec = 0;
        }
        else
        {
            tvptr = &tv;

            clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &ts_now);

            /* note that the tv_sec and tv_usec/tv_nsec values are all signed longs, so OK to subtract */
            tv.tv_sec  = ts_end.tv_sec - ts_now.tv_sec;
            tv.tv_usec = (ts_end.tv_nsec - ts_now.tv_nsec) / 1000;

            if (tv.tv_sec < 0 || (tv.tv_sec == 0 && tv.tv_usec < 0))
            {
                os_status = 0;
                break;
            }

            if (tv.tv_usec < 0)
            {
                tv.tv_usec += 1000000;
                --tv.tv_sec;
            }
        }

        os_status = select(maxfd + 1, rd_set, wr_set, NULL, tvptr);
    } while (os_status < 0 && (errno == EINTR || errno == EAGAIN));

    if (os_status < 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else if (os_status == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED (-38)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I analysed all branches and code paths in OS_SelectSingle_Impl and the related OS_DoSelect implementation. No code fragment in the provided function is provably unreachable at compile time or by logic in the shown definitions: 

- The early returns (impl->selectable false, impl->fd >= FD_SETSIZE) are runtime checks and can be either taken or not depending on runtime state. They are not statically unreachable.
- The two branches based on *SelectFlags != 0 and the else branch (flags == 0) are both reachable depending on the value pointed to by SelectFlags at runtime. Neither branch is a constant condition.
- All FD_* macros use rd_set/wr_set only when *SelectFlags != 0; the variables are declared and used in the appropriate branch — no use-after-declaration unreachable code is present.
- In OS_DoSelect the three msecs cases (msecs < 0, msecs == 0, msecs > 0) are distinct runtime possibilities; the computations of ts_end and tv are used only in the relevant branches and are reachable. The loop and its break conditions (including the case where tv becomes negative and os_status is set to 0) lead to reachable post-loop handling (OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT), so those branches are not unreachable.
- The do/while retry on EINTR/EAGAIN is a runtime loop and not statically unreachable.

Potential concerns that are NOT unreachable-code issues but that could warrant separate review (not MISRA Rule 2.1 breaches): validity of the token/index (out-of-range index or invalid token could cause out-of-bounds access of OS_impl_filehandle_table), and assumptions about FD_SETSIZE vs impl->fd values. Those are safety/robustness issues but do not make any provided code fragment unreachable.

Given the above, there are no code fragments in the supplied code that should be flagged for investigation specifically under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 (unreachable code).
